PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE:
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1996 Cognate bills: RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 March, on motion by Mr Prosser:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are told that the Retirement Savings Accounts Supervisory Levy Bill 1996 together with the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill 1996 and Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 give effect to the government's 1996 budget decision to allow banks, building societies, credit unions and life insurance companies to provide superannuation without a trust structure in the form of retirement savings accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: A retirement savings account is an account or policy which is capital guaranteed, issued to an eligible person and subject to certain criteria. By `capital guaranteed' this bill means that the balance of the account cannot be reduced through negative interest or negative investment returns or any reduction in the value of assets in which the policy is invested. The bills define what an RSA account is, who can offer one, who can take one out and, to an extent, how it must operate.

I would like to explore what exactly changes. The government is attempting to offer a new range of options for people who want or are required to take out superannuation. The provision of these services will be restricted to financial institutions and prohibited to the current direct providers of superannuation.

Assets will be portable to allow consolidation of accounts. This should reduce the number of accounts an individual may hold. Small value accounts in current systems will be able to be placed in RSAs, which are structured to preserve the investment rather than to diminish it through charges and fees. Regulation and oversight protection will be extended to cover RSAs.

I want to point out why we need to change. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said that the RSAs will introduce much needed flexibility into the area of retirement incomes policy. An RSA allows a person entering the work force to immediately establish superannuation provisions. RSAs are a recognition of how existing superannuation arrangements do not cater for the interrupted work pattern, which is the normal experience of so many women in our nation.

The great virtue of an RSA for women is that it is a facility that is available whether the woman is in or out of the work force. In a discussion on the 7.30 Report, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said that the coalition wanted to introduce RSAs as a totally new product that was particularly appealing for people moving in and out of the work force.

An account can be opened in your name, preserved and treated like superannuation. This will overcome the situation where people who are mobile in the work force or who leave the work force for periods end up with an array of small unlinked superannuation accounts being eroded by fees or incapable of providing the type of retirement savings that consolidating the funds may well do.

What will we have at the end? These are quite compelling arguments for change in the form of an additional option for superannuants which covers new ground and offers previously unavailable options. What needs to be made certain is that this government legislation will achieve the results it desires and claims it will achieve. I want to look at some of the problems that have been identified in the debate thus far and in particular elsewhere.

The opposition has indicated it will not oppose the legislation, though it has a number of concerns. Previous speakers have elucidated these concerns chiefly identified by the shadow minister for finance. The first is that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has not yet delivered its report. That is due on 6 March. It is a valid concern that there may well be some input available from the report that may improve the legislation or highlight problems that may require further attention.

In short, this bill may require further amendments. Although I am confident the coalition has done a thorough examination of the RSA concept in the development of this bill, I do not think that it should pre‐empt the findings of the committee.

The shadow minister, Mr Evans, has indicated that industry has an expectation of a lower rate of return from RSAs in comparison with current superannuation accounts. This is true, but this has to be offset against the lower risk related to RSA accounts. This will be inevitable when comparing the trust structure presently associated with superannuation with accounts that are capital guaranteed.

Why should this area be a source of concern? By the Treasurer's argument, choice will be greater for the superannuation consumer and logic would dictate that each will have the potential to select a combination of superannuation products at various times during their working life that will best suit their needs.

Provided freedom of choice and reasonable mobility can be assured, I am confident that people will not be disadvantaged by this change to the superannuation industry. Rather, I believe that improving choice will be an important benefit to potential superannuants that will give them better options and help them better plan for their future.

The opposition has also made the point that banks and financial institutions are currently able to operate super funds through subsidiaries. For example, the ANZ and the Commonwealth already do this. They have inferred the question: why should we change the current system to allow these institutions access to the seemingly lucrative investment areas of superannuation if they can already do it? I think this may well be just a red herring.

The important side to this aspect is that the product is different and that widens choice. This bill is about the offer of a new product that will improve what is available to Australians to look after themselves in their retirement. A new product may also induce financial institutions into an area of investment that previously was not attractive to them.

BREAK.PARA: A better question is: why has the government restricted provision of the RSA alternative to the new players and not to the existing providers of superannuation? This may reflect a concern that the existing players are biased in their service provision and seek to perhaps impede change. I do not think they are in a position to achieve this. The new players represent a strong alternative to the existing scenario and I am sure that they will compete aggressively for this new source of funds.

To have prevented the current superannuation suppliers from entering this market may be a more serious problem for the government. It is not consistent with their claim that their ambition with the RSAs is to improve choice. True, they have improved choice in product, but they are deliberately restricting choice of provider to a smaller than necessary group.

In this element of legislation, the government is deliberately seeking to restrict competition in the delivery of this new range of products or in this service.I am concerned that this may give some advantage to the new providers and believe that such an attempt perhaps deserves to be forwarded to the ACCC for some consideration. If the government has nothing to fear, and indeed wants to broaden choice, then it must also broaden choice of provider of RSAs to include the existing superannuation service industry.

The opposition has claimed also that the duty of a fund operator is primarily to fund members, in contrast to the banks or the operating RSAs. Their duty remains to shareholders. It is clear, as the Treasurer has stated, that fund managers also have shareholders. The difference, however, is that of scale for each operation. Superannuation providers are in that as their main business. Banks, on the other hand, are not. Already we are seeing them attempt to change the habits of consumers by imposing bank fees and charges, not necessarily because of increased costs, but rather as a disincentive to use branches and tellers for day‐to‐day transactions. For banks, these personal savings accounts are not considered profitable and so they are trying to limit the infrastructure that is associated with them.

My concern is that the banks remain more interested in the bigger investment side of their industry to the detriment of superannuation. Unless they can extract a significant share of the estimated $400 billion in superannuation potential, their efforts will be concentrated elsewhere. This will mean continued poorer returns for RSA holders. Perhaps an exclusive right to a niche market might develop their ongoing interest, but I am very wary of the government deliberately distorting a sector of the market by limiting competition in this way.

It has also been claimed that this legislation, as it stands, provides poorer protection for employees. Their employers may dictate RSA funds used for super and get a less than optimum return for the account members. There is currently no requirement for the RSA manager to provide information on the product direct to employees.

How could an employer be induced to conduct a superannuation business through a financial institution? It would be possible for a bank or other financial institution to place pressure on the employer. More likely though, incentives related to business loans or other financing might be a more appropriate way of achieving the same outcome.

This then opens potential direct conflict of interest between the employer maximising his potential and thereby improving the health of the business which employs an RSA holder, against the interests of the holder, who seeks the best financial support once he has left the business and retired. The member for Bradfield, Dr Nelson, spoke earlier to say that, in the case of industry award superannuation schemes, the employee currently has no degree of choice anyway. But I dispute that this is any reason to perpetuate something that is clearly unfair when we have the chance to change it with this legislation.

Because of the lower return one can expect from an RSA in comparison to an existing type of superannuation account, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has called for a limit of $10,000 to be applied to RSAs. The rationale behind this is that lower expected returns will diminish retirement savings available to the superannuant. This in turn will place a higher than necessary burden on the taxpayer through age pension payments. This call was also made by the coalition's previous spokesman on retirement and superannuation, Mr Connolly, but has now been dropped.

The government has instead chosen to legislate here to make RSA managers inform the account holders of their investment options once this limit is reached. The coalition has decided that real choice should be the objective and, if someone chooses to leave funds in an account that performs less well than others, that is what choice is all about. It may be a problem, however, when retirement schemes are produced that balance potential superannuation income to maximise pension subsidy to supplement that income and guarantee access to the supplementary and valuable ancillaries such as travel concessions and health care cards.

There can be no doubt that there is a real need in Australia to improve savings and that our national economic wellbeing is directly related to national savings. It has been a longstanding policy from both sides of politics that they need to convince people that money should be invested in superannuation funds. The proportion of their income has often been where the divergence of opinion has occurred.

Equally, however, it must be accepted that there is a finite money supply for application to public savings. The question is: how much of it can be or should be invested in superannuation? I would be more interested to find out what the government's own research shows concerning this. What will be the effects on the national economy if the government can achieve a significant relocation of investment from, say, stock market or commercial real estate into banks through superannuation accounts?

It is an active government policy supported by statements from the Treasurer that the single most important thing that this government has been doing for average workers, taxpayers and, therefore, superannuation contributors, is creating an environment where mortgage interest rates are low, thereby giving people more disposable income. This change to RSAs is naturally feeding off this environment and the government wants to convince people that part of this increased disposable income should be invested in superannuation accounts.

If this government wants to give people real choice and ensure the success of the RSA option, it must integrate its approach to superannuation and its relationship to the taxation system and the national economy. It concerns me that low interest rates that have been actively pursued by the government are intricately interwoven with and linked to other forms of investment that superannuation funds are currently heavily investing in. This reduces likely returns for retirement. Investors are then faced with the choice of putting their money into a lower return investment or others of higher risk and higher return.

This low mortgage policy will certainly drive some funds out of superannuation investment options anyway. Further to this, I believe that the psychological effect on investment by higher and upper middle‐income investors of the superannuation guarantee has already done this. This is compounded by talk by the government and the Democrats, who have moved to increase retirement ages, and suggestions by the Western Australian government to prevent state public servants in WA taking lump sums at all.

I have been approached by many constituents who are convinced that the coalition, like its predecessor, is about to mess around with their superannuation. They believe that superannuation of any form is a waste of investment because they cannot trust governments of either persuasion to leave them alone to let them make the long-term financial commitment needed to make superannuation investment work.

A significant concern, as people may choose to withdraw their funds or not place further discretion investment into the industry, is that it will definitely become more competitive. This could be good for many investors, but there is also a danger that some smaller or less well-known structured funds may not be able to compete and thus may fail.

In pure economic theory, this is considered perhaps a good thing, as the benefit of competition choice and the economic power that larger players can bring to the industry should generate better service. But I am concerned that in getting to a restructured, efficient and competitive industry some people may lose savings value as less competitive funds either diminish or fail. I would like to see the government explore all avenues available to it to protect the interests of those investors.

In the concluding moments, may I say that, despite my reservations, I believe that this legislation initiated by the coalition government is certainly heading in the right direction. It is certainly an improvement on the current situation. What I would like to see, however, is a more clearly integrated approach by the government to the whole question of superannuation and its place in public savings, taxation and the national economy. I do not believe that such a strategy has yet been as well demonstrated as it could have been.

Government must ensure that there is real competition provided in the superannuation industry through RSAs. In my opinion, this would be better served by promoting fair competition between existing and prospective service providers. I agree that retirement savings accounts do address the three main problems that exist under current super arrangements: lack of choice; the small balances in many superannuation accounts; and the erosion of balances by fees and charges and by the number of accounts an individual may have by the nature of our society's more mobile work habits.

In the past I have been a substantial critic of the previous government's superannuation guarantee. This was a move or perhaps a concept that had some merit in it in some ways, but unfortunately in its application it turned out to be a nightmare for many employers and employees. We had the situation, as I am sure many members would know from inquiries from their constituents, where particular employees moving around in their employment life found that their superannuation accounts had been eaten up by these charges and account keeping fees and, of course, at the end of the day, in one or two instances, had a negative net asset in their potential retirement accounts. This obviously needed to be changed. I am pleased to see that the coalition has taken this on board.

The necessity for an integrated approach to superannuation savings is absolutely critical. Anybody who has been involved in the industry or, for that matter, has attempted to look at some of the range of regulations and rules and the variety of differing products available would know only too well that, in order to remain abreast of the range of products available in the marketplace, you have to have considerable expertise. The problem is that to keep in touch with or abreast of the changes that have been introduced almost continuously over recent years requires an extraordinary effort on the part of those people who in the first instance provide the professional advice to their clients, but also on the part of the clients.

It is perfectly understandable that many people in the community do not have the foggiest idea how superannuation or retirement savings actually work and, of course, they may well be vulnerable in some instances to the wrong sort of advice. This is the problem. The more complexity and the more variety there is in, let us say, some of the legislative changes, the more difficult it is for people to be able to keep abreast of those changes.

It is absolutely critical, in order to encourage retirement savings throughout our community, that people must feel confident that when they make their investments they are in fact going to get a reasonable return for their money and are not going to see those investments eroded away in more and more tax taken by the federal government. As it turns out, the federal government's take on retirement savings these days is an absolute disgrace. I must say to you that I think anybody who is perhaps contemplating investing their money, their savings for retirement, into things like property or other areas is probably acting in a very rational way when you consider the complexity of the area and the plethora of things that are occurring in relation to retirement savings. You can well understand people saying to themselves, `Why should I bother? It is not worth it in the end.' Of course, for investment or financial advisers, when they come across clients in that position, it makes it extraordinarily difficult for them, because of this complexity, to be able to show the clients exactly how they can make their retirement savings work.

I commend the government for making this change. I have registered my concerns about the changes and I hope, at the end of the day, that this government is not going to be tempted like the previous government to continually meddle with retirement savings. If it does, it will fall into the same trap as did the Hawke and Keating governments and bring retirement savings, and the products that are available, into disrepute. We need to be able to encourage national savings. We need people to feel confident that, when they invest in superannuation retirement savings, they will get a fair return and, hopefully, will be able to have a reasonable lifestyle when they come to retire and live on their retirement income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill, the Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill and the Retirement Savings Accounts Supervisory Levy Bill, I am happy to follow the member for Moore (Mr Filing) who has given a considered, thoughtful presentation on matters pertaining to these bills. He has brought up a series of sensible criticisms, some of which he has garnered from previous Labor opposition arguments that we have put forward in regard to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up his last point first. He was asking for a more integrated approach from government to the whole question of retirement savings. There was a time in the history of this country when we did have an entirely integrated approach to retirement savings for the Australian people. The Chifley Labor government brought in the National Welfare Fund. That involved 7½ per cent extra being contributed by every Australian worker into the National Welfare Fund. It was set up on the model that existed in Britain, Germany, Holland and the other major European countries after the war.

In those countries there was great foresight in terms of what needed to be done to provide for people's retirement, and to do it by a contributory pension fund, which this one was. The great benefit of those funds was that they were clear, open and entirely transparent. The workers knew that their money was going into one fund to be invested for their future benefit. In being invested in that way, the key element, apart from the good management of those funds, was the fact that they would enjoy compound interest. The European countries and Britain, which adopted those systems, had the benefit of compound interest for more than half a century. They had very, very strong funds.

In Australia, the last Labor government had to undertake a series of reforms for a partial superannuation system. People on better incomes, people who worked for companies which provided superannuation packages, did reasonably well. But for the vast majority of Australians, apart from the pension, which was non‐contributory and unfunded, there was not a superannuation mechanism in place. So for all the, at times, heavy‐handed criticisms that the member for Moore made whilst he was a member of the coalition in opposition, together with so many coalition opposition members over so many years, of the changes the government made to superannuation, the core problem that the government faced was that they were starting from a partial system. They were not starting from the unified holistic system which existed in the National Welfare Fund.

The reason they did not start with that—and, in fact, had to end the legislation for the National Welfare Fund in 1984 or 1985—was that the National Welfare Fund had been bled of its funds in the early 1950s by the Prime Minister, Mr Menzies. He faced a credit squeeze and a funds crisis. It was his determination that the £100 million that was in the National Welfare Fund, contributed out of workers' pockets as an extra 7½ per cent levy, should go into consolidated revenue. The National Welfare Fund died as an entity from that point on.

So we in Australia have not had half a century of the workers in this country—all of them—contributing to their own retirement and contributing by helping to fund that themselves. The workers have not had the compound interest that was available to their counterparts in Britain and Europe. They have not had the unity and certainty of a system that could guarantee in Holland that people could retire on 80 per cent of their normal savings. They have not had the guarantee—whatever their income—that, because they were putting their percentage into a superannuation system or a retirement system according to their level of income, they could be assured—whether they were earning $200 or $1,000 a week—that their standard of living in retirement would match very closely what they had enjoyed during their working life.

The reason we do not have that system is that Prime Minister Menzies took £100 million out of the national welfare fund, crippled it and destroyed it. He put that money into consolidated revenue and the coalition, while it was in government under Menzies, Holt, Gorton and McMahon, has not repaid one penny of that £100 million directly to retirees who had helped to fund their own retirement. That is the reason why the Labor government, during the past 13 years, has had to start from a partial company based system, directed in large part towards those in self‐employment or towards those who enjoyed company packages. From 1972 to 1975, Prime Minister Whitlam offered people over the age of 70 the availability of the pension. The offer was made for that very reason that the national welfare fund had been crushed by Prime Minister Menzies. In recognition of the fact that, effectively, £100 million had been stolen from those workers who had contributed, Prime Minister Whitlam allowed a pension for people over 70.

So we start to talk about this bill, a new retirement savings account bill, not on the basis of an entirely unified and integrated approach to retirement savings. We talk about it now after more than half a century in which the people of Australia could have continued to build funds for their retirement. We have a country in which the levels of investment, shareholding and national savings have always been far too low. We could have had more than 50 years of the types of investment and national savings put by the national welfare fund into Australian industries and jobs and into helping to build Australia's strength and greatness. We have not had all of that because that money was taken out of the fund by stealth.

We have currently a superannuation system, essentially based on award superannuation, progressively built up primarily by former Treasurer Paul Keating, my predecessor in the seat of Blaxland. He and other Labor Treasurers have built in the idea that there should be award superannuation, and that we should build on that award superannuation from the original three per cent up to a maximum of 12 per cent. There was an absolute total and complete commitment by the Labor government to the importance of superannuation for all Australians, not just for some. That system needs to be built progressively, and it needs to be added to. The commitment on the part of the coalition to a unified integrated system of superannuation has not been evident to me during the past 14 years. The criticism that they levelled at every increase in award superannuation was manifest among a series of coalition speakers from the top to the bottom.

Equally, with this retirement savings account proposal, I am not convinced that it is much more than window‐dressing to show that the coalition has one new element to provide for people to save for their retirement, because I think there is another agenda rolling with it. It is an agenda that does not demonstrate a commitment to award superannuation. It is an agenda that does not admit to an extension of that system and to a total encapsulation of that for the future, and to making sure that that system continues to be embedded in our constitutional and legislative fabric so that it cannot be whittled away.

The three bills before us are not being opposed by the Labor Party. Our previous speakers have indicated that we would like a series of amendments to be looked at, particularly in the Senate, but we are concerned about a whole series of related things. One concern is that we think this may simply be another attempt by the coalition government to perversely undermine the good work done during the past 13 years by the then Labor government. The Labor government sought to increase national savings whilst, at the same time, providing all Australians with an equitable and secure retirement income. It is true that this policy of the coalition has been a part of their platform for some years now. We looked at it ourselves when we were in government, but, on Treasury advice, we thought better of it.

This is not a policy that will benefit the vast majority of Australian people. It is a policy that has a series of beneficiaries, but the primary one is the banking sector. For years the banks have looked jealously at the great pool of superannuation funds accumulating and the charges that could be levied on those funds. They were locked out. They knew they could only access part of that market and it cut into them that that money was going into the coffers of other companies. Some banks brought into play superannuation subsidiaries and those banks then competed with the major funds.

The banks were able to access some of the funds through those subsidiaries, but the vast majority of the money was channelled into areas and entities that they could not control. They felt that their concern for an exercise of power over the economy was undermined. They thought the power of the banks with the government was declining, despite the fact that they had been put back in place as the prime lenders, and they thought that the banks could no longer primarily influence the government in many policy areas. There were new players in the game and our banks did not like it.

BREAK.PARA: However, we know that the banks have had great support from the coalition in past years. A part of our argument is that it is because the union movement has been involved directly with award superannuation and with the major funds that have grown as a result of it that the coalition has a predilection to open up other vehicles.

We understand—because we understood the problem previously—that there is a difficulty for itinerant workers, those who move around the country from one end to the other doing seasonal work, and for those people who come into the work force on a temporary basis, leave to have children and then come back into the work force again. There are problems for those people, but those problems were addressed in the legislation we brought forward, which hit at the main reasons that are being put forward for the measures in this bill. It ensured that the superannuation funds would not bleed down the contributions of those people by excessive charges. We have seen throughout the period in which super funds have run the award schemes and others that, unless they are regulated, unless they are trammelled by the government, they will attempt to get away with ripping off the working people of Australia by imposing excessive charges. We heard no great complaint from the banking sector when they were put back in by the previous Labor government as the prime lenders in the Australian community, but lots of complaints about their feeling that they were locked out.

There are a number of questions related to these measures and to guarantees. Who will guarantee that the banks will fully disclose their fees and charges? Can we know that the banks will provide the maximum possible return to the superannuant, as is the case with current superannuation bodies? We have seen in the past that banks are particularly bad at self‐regulation on this front.

There is no guarantee that they will not continue with this kind of commercial deception. There are no formalised structures in place to underpin these superannuation funds. Currently, superannuation funds are formalised in a trust structure to guarantee the funds of those who are contributing. There are no such formal structures in this legislation for these retirement savings accounts.

Where is the independent complaints mechanism? Can we expect that the banks are going to self‐regulate and do the right thing by their contributors? I hardly think the banks will do that. I really would not insult the intelligence of the members of this parliament by saying that all banks would. I fear that there are many people who will not have an option but to contribute to an RSA.

As we have seen with the industrial relations policy of the coalition government, the idea is to let the ordinary worker be the plaything of the market. Choice is a mantra that is used by this government over and over in this legislation. Choice is a code word for driving the ordinary worker down so that employers can increase profits at their expense.

What are the costs of this scheme going to be, not just for the government but for the ordinary worker who is going to be subject to these new policies? The government has not provided any hard figures with which we can work out the likely costs that there are going to be. Instead, we have had choice and flexibility bandied about to cover up the fact that they clearly have no idea how these things are going to work in practice. They are going to leave it all up to the banks to decide. They are going to stand back and say that they met their commitment and that there is choice and flexibility no matter what cost to the workers, to the ordinary Australian people, who use these savings accounts.

Who is going to administer the schemes for the government to ensure that the legislation is adhered to? Who is going to pay for the increase in supervision and which department, if any, will shoulder the burden now that the government has admitted that it has made what it terms `accounting errors' in its budget? In addition, who is going to inform the public about their choice, provide them with the information they require and pay for that information?

We all know how the government feels about small business. We are harangued almost on a daily basis to the point—if you have not heard about it you are almost not in Australia—that the government was going to reduce the burden on small business by 50 per cent within one year of gaining office. The relevant minister has not been particularly direct and clear on how that would be done when he has attempted to answer questions in the House. But we have had one year and as to this point we have had no change.

To make matters worse now, the coalition is going to add to that burden with more paperwork, not less, for the small business people of Australia. This legislation was designed for seasonal and itinerant workers and as such there will be a multitude of new funds of varying size to cater for them. For each employee, an employer will have to transfer the required funds to each account and will have to fill out the paperwork for these transactions with their financial institution. I think that will just increase the burden, not reduce it.

Large firms will not have any problems at all with this as they already have the staff trained and tasked with dealing with these sorts of matters. It is the small and medium enterprises that are going to find that they will carry the burden of these changes. They will also need to be advised on how these changes will affect them as well as what ongoing advice they need to give and what advice they need to get concerning their responsibilities. Who is going to provide all of that? I do not think the banks are going to do it. It will be left up to the government, which is reluctant to spend any money or to provide advice to the groups that need it the most.

There are no guarantees that workers will be better off under this new system. How will they know what the choices are that are available to them? Most will not have the knowledge base to make an informed decision of this kind. These are fairly serious matters when we consider that the choices these people will make will affect their lives substantially, particularly when they retire. A poor choice made by someone either not corrected or corrected too late will lead to disappointment and pain later in their life.

Other speakers have directed their attention to a simple comparison between three people who used retirement savings accounts up to a point of raising $10,000. At the end of that period of time for the rest of their working life one person stays in the RSAs, the second person goes into a managed super fund and a third person undertakes a different approach.

The difference between the different approaches is marked—up to $90,000 between a managed superannuation fund and one of these RSAs. The point there is that if people are locked into these RSA accounts and not properly advised they will have a dramatically reduced income in retirement because these are low return accounts. They say they are flexible. They say there is choice and the government says that they will be low cost accounts, which I doubt, but they are capital guaranteed low return accounts which cannot take into account the full effects of inflation over a period of a person's working life and they cannot adequately provide for the retirement needs of Australian workers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few brief comments in summing up this debate in regard to the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill, the Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 and the Retirement Savings Account Supervisory Levy Bill 1996. I would like to foreshadow that I will be moving some technical amendments, which have been previously circulated, to the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill and the Retirement Savings Accounts (Consequential Amendments) Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I would, however, like to respond to a number of comments made earlier in the debate. First, the issue was raised of the potential of long-term costs of leaving money in RSAs. It was alleged that the government has not been honest with the public on the expected lower returns from RSAs. The government has always acknowledged, and I just emphasise that, that the RSAs may yield a lower return than is available from other superannuation products.

People invest in a whole range of things in life and they make their own choices. In that respect, the RSAs are not any different from people making choices in life about their investments. In this respect, I was interested to hear from quite a number of people from the opposition who were indicating that we were putting such emphasis on choice, flexibility and competition. Opposition speakers seemed to be indicating that Australian people, by and large, did not have the ability to make choices about where they would place their money. I would reject that. I think most Australians have a great capacity to know where they ought to be investing their money.

Particularly in regard to RSAs, what happened under the previous government was that people were forced to put their money into little accounts and, overwhelmingly, those accounts have all disappeared now. It would be interesting to know the exact figure as to how much money was put into these small accounts, the administration costs of which saw the whole lot disappear. The battlers in Australia, who generally have small accounts, have been watching their money disappear over the last three or four years. They go in every six months and realise that there is no money and, as somebody said, there were even some negative accounts. That is quite unsatisfactory.

The RSAs have been brought in to make sure that particularly itinerants, people moving around Australia, part-time workers and so forth with small accounts will be able to have a product which they can have a feel for, understand and also be able to have move with them. I think that is important.

In recognition of this issue, it will be a feature of this product that account holders must be advised of alternative products offering potentially higher returns over the longer term when account balances reach $10,000. This will assist in allowing the holder to make an informed decision about whether to retain his or her superannuation in an RSA. I think that is an important feature of this—that people are informed about alternatives, particularly if they get their accounts up to $10,000.

Second, it was suggested that a proposed government amendment will remove protection provided to employees where, in certain circumstances, moneys were to be held in trust. This amendment only applies where an RSA is not opened, for whatever reason, immediately after receiving money from an applicant. This is solely a technical amendment which recognises the commercial practices of deposit taking institutions. The moneys will not be at risk but will be required to be held in suspense in accordance with arrangements set down in regulations.

On the issue of an employer opening an account on behalf of an employee, the opposition noted that employees will not be provided with information prior to the account being opened. What it failed to mention, though, in this regard is that the information must be provided to the employee as soon as practicable after the account is opened. In addition, the employee has 14 days after receiving that information in which to close the account without penalty. So there are options there, and we believe that this is a correct balance in making sure, on the one hand, that there are obligations for employers and yet, on the other, that the opportunity for the employee is met in this way.

It was also claimed by the opposition that there is a level of complexity associated with the legislation for a product which is simple and low cost. The government rejects this claim. RSAs are to be an alternative superannuation product of benefit to the concessional regime which applies to superannuation. It is therefore essential that the current retirement income standards apply to these accounts.

It was also suggested, I think by the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), that RSAs should be prudentially regulated in a similar manner to existing superannuation, that is, through trust arrangements. This implies that regulation of RSAs will be inferior to that of current superannuation funds, and it demonstrates, I believe, a complete failure to understand the proposed regulations of the RSAs.

It is clear that prudential regulation of providers will be conducted through the existing regulatory regime; that is, by the Reserve Bank of Australia in the case of banks providing RSAs. Is the opposition really suggesting that prudential regulation by the Reserve Bank is inadequate? I do not believe that the Reserve Bank regulations are inadequate, but it seems to be an implication from what some opposition members have suggested.

Time is running out in regard to this debate, and I think we are required to get this legislation back to the House fairly quickly. That being the case, I will briefly sum up. This is an election commitment which we as a government are following through on. It is a package which many battlers in Australia will welcome and will significantly benefit from. RSAs are fully portable—that is very important—and I believe that this is a niche product with the potential to benefit a wide population group within our community.

I thank everybody who has participated in the debate. It is an area which I think all Australians, including members on both sides of the House and Independent members, are very interested in. It is about our future as a country. It is a very important part of trying to ensure that all of us have adequate living standards as people go into their later period in life.
