SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), which enacts a significant coalition election promise into law and, in turn, delivers a meaningful financial and psychological incentive to small business. Although this bill contains a number of changes, I wish to concentrate on three aspects in particular: the relaxation of capital gains tax for small business, the increased tax concessions for employee share schemes, and the simplification of tax legislation relating to Commonwealth education and training measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Small business will receive a significant boost from `like kind' of business test which has been removed in this legislation. This will allow capital gains tax exemption when capital proceeds from the sale of one business are rolled over into another business. What this means is that owners of small businesses under $5 million will not be penalised for hard work and enterprise when they reinvest in active capital assets of another business, whether it is a `like kind' of business or not.

Furthermore, the government has extended the time allowed for concession from 12 months to two years. For example, a snack bar owner can now sell their business, make a profit on the sale, go on holiday and at any time up to two years after the sale buy another business. It does not have to be another snack bar. They could purchase a gift shop, a newsagency or even a liquor store. They will not have to include the sale price in their tax return, but the gain will be deducted from the cost base of a new business.

These changes will allow them to preserve and increase their capital and plough their profits into their new business. The business person has total flexibility and it is hoped this will give them greater stimulus to expand their small business. In taking these initiatives, the government has gone further than its election commitment required. It is a real and significant reform which reduces unnecessary red tape.

This bill sends several messages to the people of Australia. Primarily, it is yet another example which shows that the Howard government is serious about delivering on its election commitments. Secondly, in addition to the recent interest rate cuts, it shows that for the first time in 13 years Australia has a government which actively helps, not hinders, small business. Finally, it shows that the coalition is serious about tackling the unemployment problem, which is Labor's legacy to this nation.

My pride in this aspect of the bill can be no better than that expressed by Mr Robert Bastian, the Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, who said in the Australian Financial Review on 4 December 1996:
It's bloody fabulous, an excellent gesture for small business. It gives a psychological lift which far exceeds the $50 million input by the Government.

Unlike the Labor Party, which stifled small business for 13 years, the coalition is doing everything possible to rebuild a strong, confident private sector. While the coalition did not create the problems for small business, we are now working to fix them. Small business needs, above all, a climate of confidence and the Howard government has made a number of practical, commonsense improvements to assist small business.

Let me at this point indulge the chamber by telling members what we have already done to get the economy going and to improve small business earnings. We have lowered interest rates. We have reduced pressure on future interest rates by cutting the budget deficit. We have reduced the provisional tax uplift from eight per cent to six per cent. We have passed the workplace reform legislation, including the repeal of unfair dismissal laws. We have increased funding for apprenticeships and traineeships—more than $1,700 million over the next four years—and we have lowered inflation.

At question time recently I asked the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to inform the House of any developments in relation to small business loan products and to explain how these products would assist small business. The Treasurer informed the House of the entry of Australia's largest non-bank lender, Aussie Home Loans, into the business lending market and explained how that would revolutionise Australia's business lending. Called Aussie business loans, they are offering business loans at 7.49 per cent. This is truly good news for small business. When we came into office in March 1996 the business lending rate was at 11.25 per cent. No wonder that in the latest yellow pages small business survey around two‐thirds of small businesses expected sales and profits to increase over the next 12 months.

I cannot emphasise enough the vital importance of confidence to the small business sector, yet we have a Labor opposition doing their level best to disparage what we are rebuilding. In the words of my colleague the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), the sloppy attempt by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and Senator Cook to cast a pall of misery across Australian small business is a clear sign that Labor is getting desperate, does not know what it stands for, and does not have any policies.

BREAK.PARA: The second point I wish to make relates to employee share schemes. This bill will increase the tax exemption from $500 to $1,000 per year, as well as make it easier for such share schemes to qualify. This is another example of how the coalition government has given employees and businesses the freedom to make their own arrangements. By giving tax incentives that promote the introduction of these schemes, Australian industries and employees will be able to look to substantial tangible benefits at the end of the day, free from the paternalistic system through which the ALP stymied productivity, growth and, of course, jobs.

Employee share schemes are also great confidence builders in that they help bind the employer and the employee into a common purpose. This scheme gives employees incentives to work productively for the benefit of themselves and their employers alike. This is another building block the government is putting in place to rebuild a vital sector of our community.

While on the subject of employer and employee benefits, I would like to draw the attention of the chamber to what we are doing about traineeships and apprenticeships. For too long apprenticeships were, I regret to say, deliberately discouraged by Labor. Over the past six years the number of apprenticeships has fallen from 62,259 to 50,436—no wonder youth unemployment was over 50 per cent in some areas. To fix this problem, the coalition already has allocated $260 million over the next 12 months through incentive payments and wage subsidies, and $1,700 million will also be allocated for this purpose over the next four years.

Incentive payments will be made to small and medium sized businesses to encourage them to recruit apprentices and trainees. Employers are eligible to receive an initial payment of $1,250 for each apprentice and trainee, followed by an additional progress payment when the trainee progresses to higher skills. A third bonus payment will be paid to an employer for each additional apprentice taken on above the previous year's intake.

In relation specifically to youth unemployment, it is appropriate at this point for me to mention the pilot program called Jobs Pathway. I recently had the privilege of launching one of these programs in my electorate. Catholic Social Response was appointed to match employers with job seekers. This highly useful program will help young people compose resumes, learn how to conduct themselves at interviews and confidently put their best foot forward when meeting prospective employers. This is yet another link in the chain of getting young people who do not want to proceed to tertiary education into the work force.

In terms of this bill, I applaud the long overdue simplification of legislation relating to Commonwealth education and training schemes. Although it is a fairly minor technical amendment, it is nonetheless a step in the right direction. By using a generic term, the terminology used in the legislation is substantially simplified and made more comprehensive. Any move to consolidate and simplify tax laws which are unnecessarily cryptic will assist in their comprehension and reduce demands made on the House's time by having to amend terms of little substantive significance.

I would like to close by telling the chamber of one of my favourite analogies. The economy of Australia was like an ocean liner steaming along at full speed when it realised it was off course. The current government had to slow the liner's momentum and turn it around. This takes time and space. Large moving bodies cannot stop suddenly, nor can the economy. It has to slow before turning and then regain momentum in the corrected direction. This is what the coalition has had to do during the past year—stop the economy moving in the wrong direction by looking at where we were going and where we should be going. Now we are gradually turning it around and getting it ready to go full steam ahead in the right direction. I support this bill for its assistance in building up business confidence. I commend the bill to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I just hope, in reference to the contribution of the previous speaker (Mrs Elizabeth Grace), that the economy does not turn out to be the Titanic and, in fact, we are rearranging deckchairs on HMAS free trade.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments today concentrate on the capital gains tax—the disposal of small business assets provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1996. The government claims that these provisions will give effect to the proposal it foreshadowed before the last election to provide rollover relief to small businesses which sell assets in order to expand or diversify. In its policy document entitled `Capital gains and fringe benefit tax reform' the coalition outlined the rationale behind this proposal by stating:

Small and medium sized businesses should be encouraged to grow and trade up. Small business is the engine room of jobs growth in our economy. Encouraging them to grow and invest more will flow through to more jobs.
I agree in general with these sentiments but I question the emphasis being give to small business alone to generate an employment resurgence, because that certainly is not going to happen.

My concern with the bill is that, while it will undoubtedly help some small businesses, the proposed legislation's definition of active asset will mean that many small businesses, which I am sure the government intends to help, will be hindered rather than helped by this legislation. As I will explain shortly, there are many people involved in small businesses who, because of the way they structure their businesses, will not be able to take advantage of these rollover provisions. There are 388,000 businesses in this country with assets less than $5 million.

I argue that these provisions may require further amendment if they are to achieve their worthy objective to encourage all small businesses in Australia to grow and add to the overall prosperity of the country. I am, however, all too aware of the unlikelihood of an amendment introduced by an Independent being agreed to. Nevertheless, I think the issues I raise deserve the close attention of all members of the House and those in the other chamber. Let me explain.

Currently, the capital gains tax provisions apply to the disposal of small business assets acquired after September 1985. The new division 17A of part IIIA to be inserted into the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 will provide rollover relief where a small business—defined as a business with net assets of less than $5 million—disposes of some or all of what the provisions refer to as active assets and replaces these assets with other active assets.

An active asset is defined in the relevant subsection of the act. One subsection sets out the meaning of active asset. Under its terms, an asset owned by a taxpayer is an active asset at a particular time if at that time, firstly, it is used or held ready for use by the taxpayer in the course of carrying on a business or, secondly, it is an intangible asset that is inherently connected with a business carried on by a taxpayer—for example, goodwill or the benefit of a restrictive covenant.

The next subsection specifies certain categories of assets which are not active assets. It states that `shares in companies' are not considered `active assets' within the terms of the act. After speaking to the Treasurer's office and to the tax office—legislators involved in designing this legislation—I have been informed that the main reason shares in companies were excluded from the active asset criteria was to ensure that share traders, people whose sole business is investing in company shares of companies like BHP, would not be able to avail themselves of the capital gains rollover relief benefits available under the provisions. I agree that these types of businesses should not be the beneficiaries of these changes.

In my mind, these provisions seek to help people involved in small business like farms, hotels, restaurants, newsagencies and the like—genuine small business people who want to sell business assets in order to expand or diversify. It is by improving the playing field for these small businesses that they may be better able to contribute to solving Australia's alarming unemployment rate, especially in regional areas. These types of small businesses are, deservedly, the targets of the benefits of this legislation and not the cashed‐up entrepreneur whose only business is sitting behind a computer gambling on the stock market and whose quite unproductive endeavour should be the target of any tax reforms in this country so the government can begin to concentrate more on revenue gathering than squeezing the last drop of blood from the current tax stones—namely, PAYE taxpayers and small business.

Unfortunately, however, because the proposed legislation specifies that shares in companies are not active assets, and many genuine small businesses run on a share basis, it appears that many of the very enterprises the government is trying to assist with this measure will in fact not be assisted at all. Let me demonstrate the effect these changes will have on one small business in my electorate.

Farmer Brown, in partnership with his wife, owns a farm valued at $1 million. At the same time, he holds a four‐fifths share in a company which owns an adjoining property valued at $5 million. He wants to sell the property he and his wife own in partnership and use the funds to buy out the remaining one‐fifth share of the company which owns the adjoining $5 million property. This is not a stock market takeover; it is an acquisition of shares in a property one‐fifth owned by the purchaser's sister in this case.

It is a very common occurrence in small business that instead of buying the actual business property and its attached assets a farmer will buy out shares in a company that owns the property. This is common in all small business but especially common in the farming sector. For example, it is common for the children of farmers to start off businesses on their own and then sell them in order to buy out their siblings' shares in their parent's farm.

It is my understanding that under the proposed legislation Farmer Brown will not be able to get rollover relief for the capital gain in this transaction simply because he is buying shares in a company which owns a property rather than buying the farm assets from the company itself. I have been advised Farmer Brown may be able to avail himself of the rollover relief only if he sells the farm assets he owns in partnership and then uses the same partnership structure to buy the larger property from the company.

If Farmer Brown and his wife were then interested in running the property on a limited liability structure, as so many small businesses choose to do, because of the benefits so obtained like separate legal identity, limited liability, flexibility and ability to attract finance, then the only way he could do this is by forming another company and transferring the ownership of the property to this new company. This transaction would attract capital gains tax but also involve the payment of significant amounts of stamp duty.

By themselves, the stamp duty implications of this hoop jumping exercise would be significant. Stamp duty rates for the sale of property in Australia range from 3½ to 5½ per cent. So for a property valued at $5 million we are talking about between $175,000 and $275,000.

This is some price to pay to obtain the benefits of incorporation. Does it not make more sense to let genuine small businessmen like Farmer Brown simply roll the funds from the sale of business assets into shares in another genuine and, in this case, like small business? The first natural question to ask is: why is this the case? The second is to ask: how can the legislation be designed so it will not have this effect? I will examine each of these.

The government may have sound reasons for excluding all company shares from the active asset criteria. It may be unworkable to treat shares in different types of companies differently. Perhaps it has something to do with the difficulty in tracking the capital gain made under one business structure which then converts to another. Perhaps the government has good reason for preferring small businesses to run on a partnership rather than on an incorporated basis, because, from where I stand, this is the message it is sending to small business.

Let me reiterate that, on my reading of these provisions, it appears to me that the government does not want businesses run on a partnership basis to swap to being run on a limited liability basis. This is a problem in that for many small businesses it is a natural progression to move from a partnership structure to a limited liability company structure as the business grows—and let us hope that the farms will grow much more over the next little while.

These provisions entered the House in a form substantially different from that contemplated by the government when it first announced them prior to the election. When first proposed, the initiative also included the requirement that the replacement asset be in another like business. However, before the bill was introduced, the government announced that it was removing the like business test, which would have allowed the rollover only to small businesses that invested in the same type of business.

I understand this change was made after the government recognised the administrative difficulties of such a test. Furthermore, after initially limiting the allowable period for reinvestment of the proceeds of disposal to 12 months, the government decided to extend it to two years. These changes were made after extensive consultation with representatives of small business groups.

It is my suggestion that these provisions may require further alteration if they are to achieve the outcomes for all small businesses that I have detailed in the early part of this speech. If the legislation is designed to help genuine small business, such as the newsagencies, printers and restaurants, and not provide relief to share traders, surely something can be included in its definitional provisions to recognise the fundamental differences between shares owned by a company that simply invests in BHPs, NABs and CRAs and those shares owned by active participants in small business. I do not see the difference between buying shares in these types of businesses and buying the assets such businesses own.

These provisions may have the effect of forcing small business to remain in a partnership rather than expanding into an incorporated company. By excluding shares in companies from the active asset criteria, these provisions cast their blanket so wide that they catch businesses they are meant to help and they encourage businesses to adopt artificial business practices which are surely not healthy for the economy. It seems clear to me that, for these provisions to work, they must recognise the unique differences between shares in companies like BHP and shares in companies formed to run the multitude of small businesses that exist in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Shares in the latter type of companies are, more often than not, owned by people who actively participate in the operation of the small business. If the government is to introduce these measures as is, then so be it. But if you are going to do something like this it makes sense to do it right. We have witnessed over the last few months the failure of the government's Austudy reforms to achieve its admirable goals of catching the rorters of the system and helping the battlers. In that case, as in this one, the principle upon which the changes were based were admirable but the execution was poor, if not inept. The result was, as admitted by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), that the people whom the legislation was meant to protect were in many cases the people whom the legislation failed. It is still happening out there.

With this legislation, the government has the chance to get it right from the start and ensure that its measures achieve the outcomes it claims they are designed to achieve. The government should look closely at the active asset criteria to see whether they really will achieve the substantive results for all small businesses that it claims and that they are designed to achieve. As they stand, some small businesses are bound to miss out on the capital gains rollover relief available through these provisions.

I briefly turn to several other partly related tax issues. We are now adding this to a tax assessment act that has tripled in size from 1,328 to 3,792 pages between 1983 and 1994. The section on capital gains tax alone is 750 pages, to be added to by these additions.

The tax system is complex, confusing and inequitable. Over 60 per cent of respondents to recent surveys criticise the difficulty, particularly in, say, compliance costs with the GST, which many regard as a nightmare. It is $300 million a year in compliance costs for that alone. One wonders what efficiency there is in that sort of tax collection. Today in the Sydney Morning Herald an article by Paul Cleary quoted Mr Michael Crouch, one of the government's business representatives on the APEC Business Advisory Council. The article said:
Australia risks being impoverished by the massive sell‐off of businesses to foreign firms . . .
Such was the allusion I made earlier to the Titanic . The article reported Mr Crouch saying:
. . . foreign control of key industries is leading to massive profit shifting offshore, poor returns to primary production and tax minimisation.
The articles stated:
He was concerned about the "level of profitability" among foreign companies operating in Australia and the amount of tax they were paying here.

The Australian Taxation Office . . . believes Australia's place in the world as a small economy with high foreign ownership has left it exposed to tax minimisation by multinationals. It is working on tougher rules . . . to reduce tax minimising through transfer pricing and other forms of profit shifting.

Let us be serious about tax reform in this country. Let us examine the whole tax system, value added tax included, have a review of the PAYE tax rates and attack those who avoid paying tax, including the ones alluded to by that prominent expert whose own business experience and export endeavours are outstanding by any measurement. Let us examine the whole tax structure, take on board the whole issue that Mr Crouch has alluded to and attack those who avoid tax paying so that we can rake in revenue and not concentrate so much on expenditure, which is hurting the PAYE tax earner in this country and particularly those on fixed incomes. Let us attack the high‐fliers to whom the Labor, Liberal and National Parties have over recent years become so beholden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) and remind honourable members that this covers a number of major things, but certainly does show that the government is honouring three major election commitments. The first one is of course the capital gains tax rollover relief for small business. The second one is the special depreciation on trading ships. The third is the employee share schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, it makes a number of technical changes to the tax act in updating references in the tax law regarding Commonwealth education training payments and the controlled foreign companies and foreign investment funds provisions to ensure that the provisions operate as intended. Also, there are the dividend imputation rules to give companies flexibility converting to the class C franking account, the commercial debt forgiveness, and some related matters on tax file number and equity investments in small to medium sized enterprises and their provisions under a number of matters related to that.

I listened with some interest to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren). He raised an interesting technical point. But I refer him to the fact that the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister, Mr Miles, in his second reading speech made a very clear point that taxpayers under the capital gains tax rollover relief who would be eligible include individuals, partners, companies and trusts. While it may be possible to find one particular exception to the rule, the fact is that the bill does make provision for those who own private companies in the rollover from one small business to another. So it does not in fact exclude that. A lot of small businesses that operate a company and choose to change from one business to another would qualify for the capital gains tax relief.

There is no doubt that this has been warmly received by many thousands of small businesses. It has clearly been something that has on many occasions restricted small businesses from expanding or changing to another business. This in many cases has led to probably continuing inefficient use of assets and inefficient use of the operator's ability and has restrained people from getting into new fields of endeavour where they not only could be more successful but also could put their capital to far more productive use.

I think one could say in summary that the capital gains tax as introduced by the previous Labor government has been one of the things that have continued to be an impediment to the growth of small business. Hand in hand with that goes the fact that, if you have got that impediment to growth, you have got that impediment to job creation.

One thing this government is working very hard to do is turn that around so that small business as the generator of jobs will be able to get on and do this. It is clear that, as a result of this bill, we will see an extra $200 million for small business per year to further encourage that expansion. I think that is a very positive thing.

It is also significant to note that there has been a removal of the `like kind' business test and at the same time an extension of the time for acquiring replacement assets. This flexibility will mean that a new asset can be acquired up to 12 months prior to the sale of an existing asset or up to two years after. I think that shows that the government has very much recognised the reality of small business in trading and in turning over from one form of business to another.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the red tape?

—I will come to the red tape. The other point to note is that the measures will come into effect from 1 July this year. One of the really strong endorsements has come from Robert Gottliebsen, the Manager Editor of Business Review Weekly . He described this as the most important corporate tax reform in 30 years. What better endorsement could you have? That is from someone who really understands business, someone who really sees the importance of the way a government approaches business and someone who has really put his neck on the line to say that that is how significant it is.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to a say a number of other very complimentary things about the current government in its approach to business. No doubt some members of the opposition find that a bit galling, but it is about time a government did listen to small business, did show that it understood small business and recognised that small business not only is the engine room of growth for this country but also provides the opportunity to reduce that terrible legacy that we inherited from the previous government.

It is interesting to look back at the history of the capital gains tax. Some of us do have a bit of a memory about these things. You do not have to go very far through the history books, just back to 16 February 1983 when a certain gentleman called Bob Hawke made this infamous quote—I will repeat it so those opposite cannot be allowed to forget:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortions. There will be no new capital gains tax.

Then in February 1985 what happened? In it comes. In May 1985, the then Treasurer Paul Keating said, `The government has decided to introduce a capital gains tax.' So much for the credibility of the former Prime Minister.

The quite remarkable thing I recall about the introduction of that capital gains tax is the financial impact statement attached to the end of the second reading speech. As I recall it, that financial impact statement made the extraordinary claim that, after five years, the Treasurer anticipated that this new tax would raise $25 million. I think after two years it had raised something in excess of $500 million. Either he was sadly misled or he had clearly grossly understated the impact it was going to have on business and, ultimately, the impact it was going to have on the ability of businesses to employ new people.

When we look at the improvements that have been put together for the capital gains tax, there is going to be a time when we are going to have to consider this further. Something I would like to see some consideration given to is the need to put a time limit on how long a capital gains tax can apply.

I raise that tonight because I believe that there is rapidly becoming a point for businesses who have owned assets since the introduction of the capital gains tax in September 1985 where it is becoming well nigh impossible to accurately and reasonably simply calculate the capital gains liability.

I would like to give two quick examples. My first one is where a business, say, a factory, was in operation prior to 1985. Since that time that business has expanded, so the factory has had new equipment installed in it. At the same time, the building has been modified because it could no longer cope as it was originally intended. Possibly also during that time some older equipment has been sold and maybe some of the factory has been subdivided to allow someone else to take part of it. I would suggest that by the time you sit down and try to calculate what capital gains tax might be applied were that factory to be sold, there would be some cases where it would be extremely difficult, extremely complex and, I would suggest, very costly. At the end of the day, I am not sure that it could be accurately assessed.

BREAK.PARA: I could cite another example where, say, someone had decided to go into retirement and invest their money in shares and had bought shares in a particular company that subsequently had a rights issue. Subsequently, that person, for good market reasons, may have decided to reduce the ownership of shares in that particular company. Then they may have gone into a dividend reinvestment scheme and there may have been some other change in the capital structure of that company and one or two other things. When you look at it, that person probably would not have shares in just one company; if they were prudent they would have them in a number of companies. You could well see the situation where if they were to choose to sell out in current times or in the not too distant future, it would be extremely difficult to accurately assess what the capital gains tax liability was on that portfolio of shares.

These two examples illustrate where I think there has to be some further consideration given in the not too distant future about where the time frame of capital gains tax is to be applied. There has to be some consideration at some stage that the cost of complying with it is probably going to exceed the amount of revenue that is likely to be gained, and certainly it will cost the individual taxpayer a significant proportion of what should otherwise be a reasonable gain on investments they have made over an extended period of time.

I would now like to turn to a couple of other aspects of this bill. Firstly, the employee share scheme again shows that the government is honouring an undertaking that it has given. It makes it quite clear that we intend to inject $15 million per year into the tax treatment for employee share schemes which most people in Australia recognise nowadays is a very important development to build on to ensure that all Australians are finding new and prudent ways to increase their savings and to invest for their future and, obviously, for their retirement. It recognises the role that employee share schemes have in strengthening employee participation in Australian business.

The bill doubles the income tax exemption from $500 to $1,000 per employee per year which, at the same time, matches the increase in the deduction available to employers. The bonus to employees will be available for shares or rights acquired on or after 1 July last year.

The bill also eases the employee participation condition for employee share schemes to qualify for the concessional tax treatment from 75 per cent to 66 per cent of employees being involved. Again, this shows that the government is making a sensible, realistic and positive contribution to making it easier to encourage employees to get involved in the ownership of the businesses in which they work.

This all shows that the government is very serious about encouraging small business. As I have said, we recognise that small business and the growth in small business is essential not only for the economy but also for increasing employment in this country. By recognising this and by recognising that we intend to keep our election commitments, we have shown that we have great faith in the future for small business. What we really want to do is see small business continue to grow.

These are just a couple of the ways in which we have honoured the undertakings, but there are a number of other things to recognise about small business. First of all, there are some 850,000 small businesses, of which probably at least half will qualify for the capital gains tax rollover relief if they choose to take advantage of it.

We also should recognise that of those 850,000 small businesses, 100,000 are in the farming sector. That is something that is very dear to my heart, representing as I do a regional seat which has a very significant number of farms. Farming is very important part not only of my electorate but also I believe of the Australian economy. It is also important to note that amongst those 850,000 small businesses 80 per cent are owned by families and 30 per cent are owned by women. Small business also contributes 30 per cent to the gross domestic product and it employs 45 per cent of the work force. It is important to put that in perspective to see just how significant small business is in the overall economy.

We have also undertaken to do a number of other things, including reduce the provisional tax uplift factor, which has seen a direct injection of cash back into the small business economy, recognising that lack of cash is the one thing that really does starve small business of the opportunity to grow and prosper.

It is also important to note the action on reducing red tape, which the honourable member opposite was asking about. There is no doubt that this is desperately needed. In the last term of Labor we saw the introduction of 800 acts affecting small business. Six hundred of these acts directly affected business and small business and another 200 of them affected small business, particularly through a flood of subordinate legislation. One thing that any small business person will tell you is that the amount of paperwork they have to comply with these days is a complete nightmare. As a consequence, the government set up a small business deregulation task force, which had as its specific objective to examine all these regulations and to see how this burden could be reduced.

We found, for example, that the average small business employing up to 19 people spends a minimum of four hours a week just complying with government regulations. This is often the equivalent of a quarter of the time that the owner or the manager spends on administration that is based on the running of the small business. The task force has made a number of recommendations on tackling paperwork. It has recognised the taxation compliance burden and what that is costing; it recognises the problems on employment for small business; it recognises the problems of collecting statistics; and it recognises the need to streamline government processes and regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what has it done?

—What has it done? The small business deregulation task force has reported and, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has made very clear on several occasions in the parliament, he will be announcing shortly, and I expect probably this month, a government response. I would have thought that all small business would be very pleased when they see that response—
—You ask small business people.

—You wait until they see it. We will see a number of changes to streamline this. I find it curious that the honourable gentleman opposite finds it necessary to continue to interject. He ought to recognise that so many of these problems were created by his government, and really he ought to be welcoming someone coming along to clean up the mess. There is no doubt that the Labor Party was not interested and had no intention of trying to do anything to encourage small business. At the end of the day I think they basically did not like small business, which could not be unionised, could not be compartmentalised and showed far too much independence for the likes of most of the Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: Through a range of these measures we are seeing a government that is determined to make sure that small business does indeed benefit. But there are a number of other things that we have already achieved that are very positive for small business, and I guess none could rate higher than the impact of financial responsibility when it comes to drawing up the budget for the Commonwealth. We have already started to reap the benefits of that. We have seen three falls in official interest rates already since this government was elected, and we are now starting to see that flow through to small business.

I think that is one of the most significant things that can be done. It shows that the financial markets have recognised the value of financial responsibility on the part of the government. It is rewarding Australia, if you like, and through that rewarding those who want to borrow money to expand a business and employ more people to be able to do it at a rate that is not usurious and at a rate that makes it attractive for small business to start to expand again.

All of that, I think, is very positive. I welcome the changes that have been made through the capital gains tax. I believe that the changes do indeed recognise some of the problems that small businesses have been facing with this tax. They recognise the opportunities small business should be given to allow it to expand or to change into another business. I believe that in the not‐too‐distant future further consideration will have to be given to the impact of the capital gains tax over a period of time. I suggest that a time limit would have to be put on the capital gains tax. I know that is not part of the bill we are debating tonight.

Nonetheless, I think this bill is a big step forward for small business. It certainly builds on the commitment the government has given to help small business. We are delivering on that commitment through the reductions in official interest rates and the changes we have made in the Workplace Relations Act. The changes take away something that really frightened small business; that is, the unfair dismissal laws. It is clear that Labor's unfair dismissal laws really were discouraging employment. This is a good bill for the parliament, a good bill for the nation and a good bill for small business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In his contribution to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has perpetuated a number of myths that surround this government's attitude to small business, when the reality is that they are short on implementation. They say such things as `the government has a strong commitment to small business'. The member for Wannon said that small business was the engine room of the Australian economy and that the small business sector was responding to his suggestion that both growth and jobs were being created under this government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this government would have both the House and the Australian electorate at large believe that it has been doing all of these things when in fact we would contend, quite cogently I believe, that all the government has really been doing is just tinkering at the edges, just dabbling at the margin.

The measures in this bill deal with capital gains tax rollover relief for the disposal of active assets used by small businesses. We believe that these measures will not, despite the government's unfounded rhetoric, necessarily do anything to increase employment growth. To this extent, the opposition has moved an amendment to limit capital gains tax rollover relief to situations where a net increase in employment will subsequently result.

The comments of none other than Dr John Marsden in yesterday's Financial Review are worth focusing on. The comments he made in the Financial Review yesterday follow the release last week of the yellow pages small business index figures. Dr Marsden's comments are perhaps best described as instructive, showing just how this government has neglected the very fundamental driving forces behind the economic well-being of the small business sector. Dr Marsden said:

BREAK.PARA: So why do small business proprietors paint such a bleak and contrasting picture to that portrayed by the Treasurer? The short answer is—a split in the economy. Growth has been where small business and jobs are not. And total economic growth slowed sharply in mid-1996.
He went on:
At the same time, small business has faced low consumption growth, a recessed housing sector and poor consumer confidence.
All this, despite three interest rate cuts. Consumer confidence remains, as Dr Marsden put it, `surprisingly weak'. Dr Marsden went on to say:

As well, the financial year growth figures quoted by Mr Costello disguise the extremely slow growth in the economy after March 1996. Growth in the expenditure‐based estimates of Gross Domestic Product through the four quarters to March 1997 is likely to be no more than 1.5 per cent, according to forecasters. This is well beneath the long‐term growth rates and well below what's needed to sustain job growth.
Dr Marsden went on to say:

To revive the small business economy will require more than periodic acceleration of housing construction across Australia. It requires a restoration of consumer confidence, and therefore consumption growth, and further penetration of export markets. The export potential is there for small business.

To digress from Dr Marsden's quote, it is not being met because of the fact that small business is being turned away from eyeing Asian and other international export markets, given the government's lack of interest in that area, particularly with respect to tariffs, export market development grants and research and development subsidies. Dr Marsden went on to say:
Cutting red tape and the regulatory burden are highly desirable reforms—
Dr Marsden, the member for Wannon and I agree with that sentiment—
and the Government's mooted policy statement in this area is keenly awaited.
Nevertheless, the Government needs to lift demand growth to ensure that small business shares in the 1997 upturn. And a healthy small business sector is a key source of employment growth.

All that pretty much flies in the face of the sentiments of the member for Wannon who, like many of his counterparts on that side of the House, talks long but acts little when it comes to initiating remedies to assist small businesses generate the sort of jobs growth that is required to sustain levels of employment above where they are now.

I turn briefly to the matter of depreciation as it affects trading ships. The withdrawal of the accelerated depreciation for shipping after the government had already ended the shipping capital grant arrangements will have a number of effects. They specifically include the fact that Australian shipowners will have less incentive to invest in new ships and, of course, less incentive to invest in new technology. As a result, the fleet will age, leading to increased costs which must ultimately be passed on to other shipping users. Further increases in capital productivity—and hence decreased manning levels—will be curtailed as the cost of new vessels becomes a disincentive to further investment.

I quote again from the Financial Review, this time from the issue of 17 May last year. I quote on this occasion Mr Lachlan Payne, who is well known to many members of this House as the Executive Director of the Australian Shipowners Association. Mr Payne said at that time that further planned investments in new shipping worth some $250 million would be shelved as a result of that retrograde legislation, particularly the abolition of the capital grants and accelerated depreciation scheme for new ships. Most countries, be they OECD or otherwise, provide fiscal assistance to their national fleets. This assistance may include depreciation allowances, concessional tax rates or concessional loans and subsidies. As such, the abolition of the current assistance will not create a level playing field for the Australian shipping industry—

PARA.TAB: Mr Sawford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It will especially not create a level playing field with respect to comparisons in the international market. It will place the industry at a distinct competitive disadvantage, as the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), who has a shipping based constituency, has been so timely in reminding me.

BREAK.PARA: Australian ship owners and workers alike have made significant gains in productivity and competitiveness in the last decade. Since 1989, over $2 billion has been committed to investment in ships with the result that the Australian fleet is something like half the age of the world's shipping fleet.

Manning levels on Australian ships cruising international waters have fallen from an average of 31.6 seafarers in 1986 to 18.4 seafarers in 1995. The minister conceded in his second reading speech that this is now consistent with international standards. He also intimated that in 1992‐93 industrial disputes had hit their lowest level of the decade, when only 23 ship days were lost due to crewing disputes.

These are the sorts of statistics the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) might reflect upon when he embarks upon his campaign against the Maritime Union of Australia throughout the course of this year. It is unfair and unjust to attack an industry that is making such progress halfway through its restructuring program, merely to satisfy the government's disdain of that same Maritime Union of Australia. Perhaps, to a lesser degree, that may well apply to the shipping companies. It would also serve as an omen of things to come, I believe.

The previous Labor government, I contend, had a fine record in the development and implementation of sector‐ specific industry policy. The current government could learn much from that example. In fact, many industry based bodies—Bert Evans perhaps tops that list—have cried for at least something of a visionary industry policy statement to emanate from this government. The best Mr Evans could muster was a comment to the effect that the jury was still out. We contend that the jury is not out but that this government has no vision for industry and no industry policy.

Whether we are working with the Button plan for the reform of our automotive industry, which saw exports quadruple from some $400 million in 1984 to over $1.5 billion in 1994 with an expected $2 billion to be reached by the year 2000, whether we are working with companies in the pharmaceutical industry such as Glaxo and Faulding or whether we are working with the phasing out of tariffs in the textile, clothing and footwear industry, the great success in each of these industry specific sectors was predicated on the extensive and inclusive consultative process which involved all the players—whether they be employers, union or government—working together in pursuit of the best outcomes for all concerned.

Following on from the fine work done by a former minister for transport, the Hon. Ralph Hunt, in commissioning Sir John Crawford to begin a process of encouraging the key players in Australian shipping industry to come together to consider the future development of the industry, the Labor government was responsible for setting up the Maritime Industry Development Committee.

An industry development package was subsequently crafted from this process which was based upon three fundamental underlying tenets. The first of those tenets was that unions involved accepted that changes to work practices were necessary to improve efficiency. The second was that ship operators would invest, where commercially feasible, in high technology to promote and facilitate new crewing arrangements. The third was that the government would provide financial incentives to facilitate this ongoing process of reform. It was this same approach by the previous Labor government which achieved real results in Australia's shipping industry. By contrast, the coalition government's approach is, I contend, piecemeal and antagonistic. Mr Lance Hockridge from BHP Transport so lucidly stated:
Removing this assistance without at the same time bringing in ways for the industry to reduce costs by at least the same amount creates a hiatus where we cannot provide competitive shipping services.

Mr Hockridge went on to say that he believed there was nothing wrong with subsidies. Indeed, the egalitarian nature of Australian society is underpinned by subsidies throughout its economic structure.

I agree with those sentiments. However, I have a significant problem with the sheer ignorance demonstrated by those opposite when claiming during shipping debates in the past that they know what seafarers do because they have eavesdropped on conversations in pubs which these particular members might own or because one of them might have worked on a ship for a short period of time some 10 or 15 years ago. I contend that that is not a sufficient background or basis upon which to make the misguided statements that have been emanating from the mouths of those opposite.

It is on that basis that I sincerely hope the government's approach to the Australian shipping industry is not a forerunner for their broader industry policy, if one ever emanates. Australian industry and our country as a whole cannot afford it. To that end, I urge honourable members to oppose this bill.

I want to touch briefly on the question of employee share acquisition schemes. It is perhaps pertinent to quote at some length the former member for Bradfield, Mr David Connolly, who explained the benefits of employee share acquisition schemes in 1995. Mr Connolly, who was dumped as the member for Bradfield stated:

The concept of employee share ownership in terms of taxation support in this country goes back about 17 years. I think it is fair to say that, when the concept was initially developed, it had bipartisan support. Both government and opposition accepted the clear advantages which were to be found in having a mechanism by which people would be encouraged to make contributions through their income—normally by salary sacrifice type techniques—towards investing in the company which was employing them.
Mr Connolly went on to state:

The advantages underlying the concept of worker participation through share ownership can best be described as follows: they reward good performance and the attainment of specific business objectives; they give the recipients a positive incentive to increase their company's productivity and profitability; they increase industrial harmony; they help create a greater awareness of the company's operations; they encourage greater employee identification with shareholder interests and with the company's interests; they assist in remunerating staff properly and in line with overall market conditions; they can keep the fixed component of wage costs at a lower level than would otherwise be the case; they are a motivational tool which is good for morale; they can inspire greater loyalty to the company; they can provide another form of saving for retirement and they can do so without restrictions applying to conventional superannuation; they are tax effective; and they can help to attract and retain key staff.
He concluded by stating that this mechanism was developed initially in the United States, which is regarded somewhat euphemistically as the home of capitalism.

Those on this side of the House have long supported and encouraged the growth of employee share acquisition schemes. In fact, this side of the House will, in the main, be supporting the government changes in this bill. However, it is our contention that the government has made it more difficult for the majority of employees in any one organisation or any one company to participate in the share ownership scheme which, as put by Mr Connolly, provided such benefits to individual employers, companies and the economy as a whole. We are hopeful that that is something the government will address.

In conclusion, we do question the move to relax the minimum proportion of the work force which must be invited to participate in share acquisition schemes from 75 per cent to 66 per cent. Indeed, as I say, this makes it harder for most employees to participate in the schemes which were lauded by Mr Connolly as being of such great benefit. Accordingly, to that end, we have moved an amendment which I hope will gain the support of both sides of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1996. There is a lot of legislation in this bill—10 items. Specifically I will speak on three of them and, in particular, the changes being made to the capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary though, the first two areas I will comment on—picking up on comments made by the previous speaker—relate to the employee share schemes. I think the move being made by this government to encourage employees in enterprises to participate through equity and share ownership in companies is a very positive one. Basically, it gives employees the opportunity to own part of the business, to give them a greater sense of propriety, ownership and reward. To that effect, the concessional tax treatment for shares, 13A, is to be amended in two areas. One is to increase the tax exemption for employees from $500 to $1,000 per employee for each year, with a matching deduction from employers—and this is a good incentive with which to encourage that. Likewise, this will benefit not just shares but also rights issues acquired after 1 July 1996.

The number of employees to participate through the concessional tax treatment will be reduced from 75 per cent to two-thirds. This is also very positive because it allows more employees to participate in schemes rather than, as at the moment—as certainly happens in many large public companies—the only share equity available being offered to senior executives. Frequently, unless corporations are very large, the 75 per cent level is not reached. So if it is reduced to two-thirds, it will allow more companies to provide this measure to their employees.

What better way for an employee to prosper than to have equity in their own business or company? This was certainly the case with some of the larger public floats, such as the Commonwealth Bank and, indeed, it will be the case with Telstra. Naturally, there will be a tax deferral on that if employees participate after 10 years, and that cost to the government will be around $15 million.

Another area is dividend imputation. Because of the changes in the corporate tax rate—initially that was at 39 per cent, a few years ago it went down to 33 per cent and now it is going back to 36 per cent—there is a necessity to develop a new class of share, which will be class C, particularly for franking credits and to allow a transfer between those different sectors as we move into a higher tax regime for a corporate Australia. Those amendments will be coming through in this financial year.

BREAK.PARA: The changes to capital gains tax are the really interesting part of this bill, and it is encouraging that this government is acknowledging that. This is one of the biggest benefits to be gained by small business. I think it is important to go back and look at the high tax regime legacy of the previous government. In the 13 years the ALP were in office, we saw a dramatic increase in taxes payable whilst they also became incredibly more complex. There was even a doubling in size of the Tax Pack.

Look at the actual size of the Income Tax Assessment Act from 1983 to 1994. In 1993, it was 1,328 pages. The act now has 3,792 pages. That is almost a threefold increase, not just an increase in different forms of taxation but in red tape. It is the priority of this government and of the small business task force which will be bringing down its recommendations shortly—I believe they are before cabinet—to reduce that compliance burden by 50 per cent. Even the capital gains tax legislation, introduced by the ALP on 19 September 1985, is now 750 pages long.

When we look back at those years of the Keating‐Hawke stewardship, we see that we had the capital gains tax initially and then the FBT. We had the escalations in sales tax, wholesale tax and excise. We had the superannuation tax and we had the Medicare levy increase. We had our Commonwealth debt raised by 300 per cent. It was a spend, spend, spend regime with added taxations. Regrettably, in some areas they took away deductions—one was obviously in superannuation—and one, of course, was in health where we have major problems in addressing some of our Medicare issues because of a lack of funding for private health insurance.

But it was in the area of capital gains tax where there was the hardest blow on small business. There was a need to increase revenue, but it was in the small business sector where we saw record bankruptcies during that period and record hardship. This amendment to the bill, which follows from the amendments of budget night last year, is to give greater flexibility to small business proprietors in their tax planning. This was one of the pre‐election commitments that we made and we are actually going further with the changes being advocated in this bill.

It is particularly important to note, in dealing with capital gains tax for many small businesses and for many employees, that this concerns their savings. They do not have their own superannuation schemes. They certainly have them for their employees, which they are required to under super guarantee legislation. But for many the actual realisation of the sale of their business is their nest egg for retirement. There were changes made in the budget to allow a rollover of up to $500,000 for small business into retirement. There were also provisions that people could sell their business as long as they transferred it into a like one. That produced problems and that is what this legislation is aimed at rectifying.

The report of the House of Representatives Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Small business Australia really was the beginning; changing the notion of a capital gains tax and also looking at some of the opportunities, thus bringing forward the recommendations that we are talking about tonight. This legislation is designed to remove the `like‐kind business test' and to broaden it so that you can invest in any type of business as long as it is within a prescribed period. The original legislation passed in the House after the budget was for it to have 12 months. That period has now been extended to 24 months. If you dispose of your business, you have that time period in which to invest in a new asset—to go into another business. That applies to individuals, partnerships, companies and trusts—they are all eligible for rollover relief.

One area where there is a cap placed and where there has not been a change concerns the limit of $5 million. The net business assets cannot exceed that limit. You have to be underneath that provision to take advantage of that capital gains tax provision. In 1997‐98, it is going to cost the government $200 million and the following year the cost will be $215 million. We recognise there is a cost to the community and to the taxpayer, but this area is exactly where we need to kickstart the economy.

Small business is our largest employer. We are seeing, through out budget mechanisms, very low interest rates, a low inflation environment and the right environment in which to expand, particularly with the changes to industrial relations and with the abolition of unfair dismissal provisions. However, there has to be a sweetener so that if people are prepared to put in the hard work—the blood, sweat and tears—they should be able to take advantage of a capital gain when they sell their business, either for retirement or while upgrading to a larger one.
Indeed, when the announcement was made, Robert Bastian, from the Council of Small Business Organisations, said:
It is absolutely fabulous, an excellent gesture to small business. It gives a psychological lift which far exceeds the $50 million input by the government.
Also, Kurt Rendall, from the Institute of Chartered Accountants, said:
The decision highlighted the difference between the coalition government and its predecessor.

The previous speaker was talking about ships. Glaxo has never been in the business of building ships, nor is it a small business because under your previous government big business never made bigger profits in corporate Australia. Is it not an irony that you are meant to represent the working class man, the battlers? What is interesting is the verdict that was given on 2 March 1996, which saw one of the biggest routings for the Labor Party. It was from middle income Australia, it was from the battlers in Australia, it was from all those small business proprietors who have been forgotten by your government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you've done for small business in 12 months.
—Even if you look back at the statistics of small business bankruptcies, it all happened under your stewardship, my dear friend.
—Come on, tell us!
—Order! The member for Port Adelaide.
—He's provoking me.
—The member for Port Adelaide! I think there is mutual provocation.

—I think it is terribly important that the member for Port Adelaide, who is obviously listening intently to this address, recognises that some of those forgotten people, certainly the true believers, were let down by the previous government. Indeed, look at some of their icons, particularly George Campbell. George Campbell is seen as a great authority and oracle within the Labor Party and is deeply respected by them. He did say on 24 February 1997:

BREAK.PARA: I don't think the party—
that is, the Labor Party—
knows or has a clear perception of what it stands for or, more importantly, what it wants to achieve in terms of development of our society.

That is what this government is about, trying to provide some real incentive, some development for the biggest employer—small business. I note also another leading light in the Labor Party, Gary Gray. I think this is a point that the member for Port Adelaide should take on board. He said:

If we had on more occasions, as a government, said that we were sorry and acknowledged where we got things wrong, then the result in March of last year would have been very different. I'm not saying we'd have won, but I'm saying it would have been different.

That is precisely the message that the opposition should take. They should be supporting these bills, particularly the one for small business. It allows a mechanism whereby those people in small business can save, particularly for their retirement, particularly if they are rolling over capital. It is a way of building up savings. I believe that at least this is an incentive for many of those small business, if they are taking out a high dividend repayment schedule or they are draining the company for cash, to plough it back in. If small businesses prosper, they start to employ more people and it has to be beneficial for the whole community.

There are three incentives in the bill: employee share schemes, indeed, if small businesses become bigger businesses then they can have employee share schemes; the dividend imputation, whereby they can start to pay dividends; but, most importantly, positive changes to the capital gains tax, whereby business can roll over into any other type of business as long as it is within a certain time frame. Small business can take advantage of those incentives and be more flexible in their business planning. I commend this bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tuckey) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 4 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made by APEC in 1996 towards competition policy convergence.
(2) What action has the Government taken to accelerate progress referred to in part (1) as a key aspect of fair trade liberalisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Although a new issue on APEC's trade liberalisation and facilitation agenda, work on competition policy has focused on enhancing the competitive environment in the Asia‐Pacific region through improvement of dialogue on trade and competition policy, promotion of cooperation and the provision of technical assistance for those economies which have not established competition policy regimes. This need for enhanced transparency and cooperation will increase with greater globalisation of production and the use of domestic policy actions which impact on trade.

Work in APEC on competition policy in 1996 was carried out on two fronts: one, the Individual Action Plans (IAPs) of the eighteen APEC member economies; and two, the Collective Action Plans developed by the Committee on Trade and Investment (CTI). As part of the IAP process several developed economies have undertaken to maintain a competitive domestic environment and enhance transparency, while some developing economies have undertaken, over time, to either draw up competition policy rules or consolidate existing rules and practices to prevent anti‐competitive practices.

As part of the collective action agenda a workshop was held in Davao, Philippines, in August 1996 to develop an understanding of the interrelationship between competition policy and deregulation and trade and investment policy and to explore the interrelationships between regulatory policies and trade liberalisation. Officials from the Treasury and the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) presented papers at the Davao workshop. Another workshop on competition policy is planned for Quebec City in May next year.

(2) Australia strongly supported APEC work on competition policy in 1996. As part of the IAP consultation process the Government has raised with other member economies commitments made on competition policy in their individual IAPs and sought to improve these commitments over 1996. At the recent APEC Ministerial and Leaders Meeting in Manila and Subic Bay Economic Leaders asked APEC economies to work towards improving their respective IAPs in all areas covered by the Osaka Action Agenda, including on competition policy, by the time they meet in Vancouver, Canada next year. APEC Trade Ministers, after taking into account the views of the business community, will review IAPs in mid‐1997.

At the same time Australia is actively supporting the collective action agenda, particularly in the provision of technical assistance. Australia is currently participating in a technical assistance survey, which aims to share experience in the operation of competition policies and laws with other economies and is supporting a Chinese Taipei proposal for the establishment of a regional competition policy database. At a bilateral level Australia was also involved, through the ACCC and the AusAid Support Program, in providing training for competition policy practitioners from the region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard , 18 November 1996, page 6935) concerning 38 Chinese boat persons, is he able to say (a) who acquainted those persons with their rights of action under law for compensation and access to legal aid, (b) who decided, and where was it decided, that those persons, as illegal immigrants, were entitled to legal aid and compensation and (c) whether action has been taken against the Commonwealth officers who made decisions to detain those persons beyond legal time limits.

(2) What have been the total costs to the Commonwealth associated with the (a) arrest, (b) detention, (c) accommodation, (d) surveillance, (e) legal expenses, (f) administration, (g) compensation and (h) other expenses associated with those persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) I do not know who acquainted the persons from the Isabella boat with their rights of action under the law for compensation or access to legal aid. This would obviously be a matter between a client and his or her lawyer or adviser.

(b) I do not know what arrangement there was between the lawyers and their clients regarding the payment of their legal fees. In accordance with usual practice, my Department provided funding for assistance with primary and review applications through Australian Lawyers for Refugees Incorporated.

In respect of the entitlement to compensation, Justice Wilcox of the Federal Court determined on 11 April 1996 that two representative persons from the Isabella group had been unlawfully detained. That finding by the Federal Court meant that compensation would be ordered by the Court following a hearing to determine the quantum of damages. Such a hearing was listed to commence on 4 December 1996. Prior to that time the matter was settled.
(c) No action has been taken against Commonwealth officers in relation to the detention of the Isabella group.

The detention provisions were applied by my Department in good faith in accordance with the then understanding of the legislation. Justice Wilcox accepted that there was no evidence of any mala fides on the Department's behalf.

(2)(a) I am unable to provide details of the total cost to the Commonwealth of the search and rescue operation. My Department incurred costs of around $43,000 for the transport of the Isabella boat group from Darwin to the Port Hedland Immigration Processing and Reception Centre (IRPC), and for overtime worked by the WA Police Service during the search.

(b-d) and (f) The cost to the Commonwealth of keeping the 38 persons in detention at the Port Hedland IRPC is estimated to be $960,000. This amount was calculated using a per diem rate of $44 per day, based on actual costs incurred at that time, for the provision of health care, education, welfare, interpreters, security, administration, general maintenance, utilities, catering and cleaning services at Port Hedland.

(e) Legal costs to the Commonwealth incurred to date have totalled $587,329, including payments of $118,016 to Australian Lawyers for Refugees Incorporated for application assistance. These expenses do not include a small number of costs associated with the Australian Government Solicitor receiving instructions in several `Isabella' related matters which did not progress, and in-house legal costs incurred by my Department.
(g) The parties to the settlement agreed that its terms should remain confidential.
(h) The Commonwealth also incurred a cost of approx $21,700 for fares from Port Hedland when these 38 persons were released from detention.
